III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 7/10/24, all the children on Pod 1 were walking around like
zombies all day and were dizzy. It was discovered the children
were drunk, except Youth A. The children made their own
homemade alcohol by using fruit, orange juice and sugar. The
children let this mixture sit in the window and ferment and then
when they drink it, they get drunk. Staff noticed the children's
behaviors and suspected they were drunk. This was reported to
management, and nothing has been done.
Investigation This complaint was assigned on 07/12/2024 and investigated in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist.
Complainant 1 was interviewed on 07/12/2024. Complainant did
not witness the incident firsthand but was informed of the
allegations by Complainant 2.
Administrator was interviewed at the facility on 07/12/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Administrator reported they
are not aware of any incident involving Youths making an
alcoholic drink with orange juice and sugar. Administrator denied
staff have made reports of this happening and nothing has been
done. Administrator did not have any incident reports dated for
07/10/2024 for Pod 1.
Therapist was interviewed at the facility on 07/12/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Therapist reported she has
weekly meetings with the youths at the facility and no one has
reported this happening. Therapist was on Pod 1 all day on
07/10/24 and she did not observe the youths walking around like
zombies or appearing to be under the influence of alcohol.
Youth A was interviewed at the faculty on 07/12/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth A has been at the
2

facility for four months and is placed on Pod 1. Youth A denied
anyone on the Pod had made an alcoholic drink out of orange
juice and sugar. He further denied observing anyone on the pod
walking around like zombies. Youth A reported all his needs are
being met and expressed no concerns.
Youth B was interviewed at the facility on 07/12/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth B has been at the
facility for two weeks and is placed on Pod 1. Youth B denied
having witnessed or being involved with making an alcoholic drink
with orange juice and sugar. Youth B further denied seeing
anyone acting strange or walking around like zombies.
Youth C was interviewed at the facility on 07/12/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth C has been at the
facility for four months and is placed on Pod 1. Youth C denied
witnessing or being involved in making alcoholic drink with orange
juice and sugar. Youth C has not witnessed anyone acting like
zombies. Youth C reported all his needs are being met and
expressed no concerns for the facility.
Youth D was interviewed at the facility on 07/12/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth C has been at the
facility for two months and is placed on Pod 1. Youth D denied
having any knowledge of anyone on the Pod making an alcoholic
drink or witnessing the youths on the pod walking around like
zombies. Youth D refused to answer any other questions and
walked out of the interview room.
Complainant 2 was interviewed via telephone on 07/23/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Complainant 2 reported she
did not witness the incident but heard about it from Youth E, who
is on Pod 4. Youth E told her he heard that youths on Pod 1 were
making alcoholic drinks and were drunk. She was asked how
Youth E would know that since the youths don’t interact with
youths that are not on their pods, and she replied that people talk.
Staff 1 was interviewed at the facility on 07/23/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 1 is a direct care staff
member and has been working at the facility for one month. Staff
1 has completed all new hire training. Staff 1 works first shift and
was working on Pod 1 on 07/10/2024. Staff 1 denied witnessing
any of the youths making an alcoholic drink with orange juice and
sugar and further denied the youths on the pod were acting like
they were under the influence of alcohol. Staff 1 is not aware of
3

anything being found in the youth’s rooms that would suggest they
are making an alcoholic drink.
Staff 2 was interviewed at the facility on 07/23/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 2 has been working at
the facility for one year. Staff 2 denied witnessing any of the
youths making an alcoholic drink or walking around like zombies.
She recalled an incident in May where she saw a Styrofoam cup
in Youth 3’s room and reported to this to Supervisor.
Supervisor was interviewed at the facility on 07/23/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Supervisor has been
working at the facility for two years. Supervisor denied witnessing
or hearing that youths on Pod 1 were making an alcoholic drink
with orange juice and sugar. He reported random room searches
are conducted when youths are not in their rooms and he has not
heard that anything has been found to indicate that this is
happening on the pod. Supervisor recalled Staff 3 completing a
room search on Youth D’s room and he found a Styrofoam cup
with orange juice. Youth D had reported it was juice left over from
his breakfast. Supervisor denied any incidents where the youths
were observed walking around like zombies.
Youth E was interviewed at the facility on 07/23/2024. Youth E is
placed on Pod 4 and does not have any contact with the youths
on Pod 1. Youth E denied witnessing or hearing that Youths are
making alcoholic drink on Pod 1 or any other Pods. Youth E
denied telling staff he heard that youths were making an alcoholic
drink with orange juice and sugar. Youth E reported no concerns
regarding staff or the facility.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 07/26/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 3 denied every
witnessing any youth under the influence or hearing any staff or
youth talking about youths making alcohol drink. He recalled one
incident involving a room search completed on Youth D’s room on
05/22/2024. He found a Styrofoam cup with some orange juice in
which Youth D said this was his juice left over from breakfast. He
said he threw it out. He denied finding anything else.
Tour Observation:
A tour of the facility occurred on 07/12/2024 in collaboration with
MDHHS Specialist. Pod 1 was observed to have 10 bedrooms,
some of the bedrooms do have windows. The windows are facing
the bedroom doors which has a glass window, so the windows are
visible from outside of the room on the main pod.
4

Documents Reviewed:
• Unusual Incident Report dated 05/22/2024 completed by
Staff 3 was consistent with Staff 3’s interview.
• Daily Room Search Tracking dated 06/26/24, 07/06/2024,
07/11/2024, and 07/19/2024 completed by Supervisor. No
incident reports were produced as a result of these room
searches.
• The agency Supervision Policy: Staff shall maintain within
continuous line of sight supervision when youths are
outside of their bedrooms. Line of sight supervision is
defined as “coordinating all activities of the residents under
your supervision so that visible contact is maintained, and
the actions of resident are under observation at all times.”
• The agency Critical and Unusual Incidents Policy. All
employees are responsible for documenting any and all
Unusual (out of the ordinary) Incidents involving youth. All
Unusual Incidents must be recorded on the appropriate
Unusual Incident Witness Statement by the staff person(s)
witnessing or involved in the incident prior to the end of the
shift in which the Incident occurred. The Manager or
Supervisor must complete a summary documentation of the
Incident before the Supervisor completes their scheduled
workday.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance with the rule based on
interviews with staff and youths. There is no supporting evidence
these allegations occurred.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
